elements.content: Three new 1,4-phenylenediacrylate bridged Mn(II) and Co(II) complexes of molecular formulas {[Mn2­(ppda)­(phen)4­(H2O)2]­(ppda)2­(H2O)} (1), {[Co­(ppda)­(dpyo)­(H2O)3]·4(H2O)} n (2), and {[Co(ppda)­(bpe)]·(0.5H2O)} n (3) [ppda = 1,4-phenylenediacrylate; phen = 1,10-phenanthroline; dpyo = 4,4′-dipyridyl N,N′-dioxide; bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)­ethane] have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies, and low-temperature magnetic measurements. The structural determination reveals that complex 1 is a discrete dinuclear species, 2 is a 1D polymeric chain, while 3 is a three-fold interpenetrated α-polonium network. Hydrogen-bonding interactions, formed by coordinated and/or lattice water molecules with ppda oxygen and π–π stacking interactions of aromatic rings, lead to a 3D supramolecular architecture in both complexes 1 and 2. Low-temperature magnetic study shows antiferromagnetic coupling in all the complexes. In addition, their electronic and fluorescent spectral properties have been investigated.

The structural determination reveals that complex 1 is a discrete dinuclear species, 2 is a 1D polymeric chain, while 3 is a three-fold interpenetrated α-polonium network. Hydrogen-bonding interactions, formed by coordinated and/or lattice water molecules with ppda oxygen and π-π stacking interactions of aromatic rings, lead to a 3D supramolecular architecture in both complexes 1 and 2. Low-temperature magnetic study shows antiferromagnetic coupling in all the complexes. In addition, their electronic and fluorescent spectral properties have been investigated.

elements.content: Metal–organic hybrid materials built from 3d metal ions and organic bridging ligands have become a very attractive research field for chemists due to their intriguing structural diversity based on supramolecular assemblies and potential applications as functional materials in fields of catalysis, porosity, magnetism, luminescence, conductivity, sensing, nonlinear optics, and chirality. The compositional/structural diversities of metal–organic hybrid materials may be tuned by a suitable choice of ligands as well as of metal ions, because the variation of backbone flexibility, substituent group, molecular size, and symmetry of organic linkers can result in materials having different structures and properties. A literature survey shows that the most commonly used strategies for the synthesis of metal–organic hybrid materials are the use of (a) anionic bridging ligands, which, in addition, can partially or fully counterbalance the charge of the metal centers and (b) neutral spacers to increase the possibility of enhancing the dimensionality of compounds, and charges neutrality is assured by noncoordinating anions. Thus the selection of suitable building block can assemble into structures with specific network topologies. The use of long spacers (rigid/flexible) in the quest of porous materials often yields to interpenetrated networks with reduced/no void space, with a few exceptions where some amount of void space persists even after interpenetration. The appearance of interpenetration is due to the natural tendency of molecular building blocks to pack more efficiently in the crystalline state. A large number of interpenetrated structures have been reported ranging from 2-fold to beyond 10-fold. It is interesting to note that the interpenetration between the same networks is rather common, and we have already reported some examples comprising different topologies of interpenetration.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic hybrid materials built from 3d metal ions and organic bridging ligands have become a very attractive research field for chemists due to their intriguing structural diversity based on supramolecular assemblies and potential applications as functional materials in fields of catalysis, porosity, magnetism, luminescence, conductivity, sensing, nonlinear optics, and chirality. The compositional/structural diversities of metal-organic hybrid materials may be tuned by a suitable choice of ligands as well as of metal ions, because the variation of backbone flexibility, substituent group, molecular size, and symmetry of organic linkers can result in materials having different structures and properties. A literature survey shows that the most commonly used strategies for the synthesis of metal-organic hybrid materials are the use of (a) anionic bridging ligands, which, in addition, can partially or fully counterbalance the charge of the metal centers and (b) neutral spacers to increase the possibility of enhancing the dimensionality of compounds, and charges neutrality is assured by noncoordinating anions. Thus the selection of suitable building block can assemble into structures with specific network topologies. The use of long spacers (rigid/flexible) in the quest of porous materials often yields to interpenetrated networks with reduced/no void space, with a few exceptions where some amount of void space persists even after interpenetration. The appearance of interpenetration is due to the natural tendency of molecular building blocks to pack more efficiently in the crystalline state. A large number of interpenetrated structures have been reported ranging from 2-fold to beyond 10-fold. It is interesting to note that the interpenetration between the same networks is rather common, and we have already reported some examples comprising different topologies of interpenetration.

elements.content: Di- or polycarboxylates have also been used to form robust frameworks, since, in this case, functional groups exhibit a variety of coordination modes. Several groups as well as our lab reported the synthesis and characterization of a large number of carboxylato-bridged multidimensional architectures in the presence of nitrogen/oxygen donor co/bridging neutral ligands. p-Phenylenediacrylic acid (H2ppda), as a member of multidentate aromatic polycarboxylic acids, possesses special conformations with a 180° angle between the carboxylic groups and versatile coordination modes (Chart ). It has been scarcely used to construct coordination polymers, although it can function as a mediator for transmitting the exchange interaction between paramagnetic metal centers. To our knowledge, only a few compounds of ppda have been reported in the literature. Since the metal–metal distance through the ppda2– ligand is above 13 Å, the bridging spacer does not effectively transmit the magnetic exchange. However, this anion sometimes functions as a bridging ligand with connection of the type M-O-C-O-M that exhibits spin-canted ordering, behaving as ferromagnet and metamagnet.

elements.content: The transition-metal ions are often used in syntheses based on the interest of their magnetic properties. It is interesting to note that several 3D metal–organic hybrid materials have shown long-range magnetic ordering with values of the critical temperature (T c) up to 70 K. Recently, several papers have confirmed that highly anisotropic Co(II) ions can show slow magnetic relaxation dynamics that lead to the preparation of single ion magnets, which have potential applications in molecular spintronics, ultra-high-density magnetic information storage, and quantum computing at the molecular level. On the other hand, isotropic Mn(II) was also used for simplicity and easy understanding of the magnetic coupling established through the ppda2– ligand and its multidentate nature offers the possibility to grow higher dimensional metal–organic frameworks with tunable magnetic properties depending on the coordination geometry of the complex. Therefore, it is important to study the potential and versatility of this linker in terms of both coordination chemistry and magnetic exchange mediator.

Therefore, it is important to study the potential and versatility of this linker in terms of both coordination chemistry and magnetic exchange mediator.

elements.content: In this contribution, ppda was employed to synthesize three novel coordination compounds, namely, {[Mn2­(ppda)­(phen)4­(H2O)2]·(ppda)·2(H2O)} (1), {[Co­(ppda)­(dpyo)­(H2O)3]·4(H2O)} n (2), and {[Co­(ppda)­(bpe)]·(0.5H2O)} n (3) [ppda = 1,4-phenylenediacrylate; phen = 1,10-phenanthroline; dpyo = 4,4′-dipyridyl N,N′-dioxide; bpe = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane]. These compounds exhibit diverse structural dimensions: 1 is a discrete dinuclear complex, 2 is a 1D coordination polymer, while 3 is a 3D three-fold interpenetrated network. Hydrogen-bonding and π–π stacking interactions of aromatic rings lead to a 3D supramolecular architecture in both complexes 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: In this contribution, ppda was employed to synthesize three novel coordination compounds, namely, {[Mn2(ppda)(phen)4(H2O)2]⋅(ppda)⋅2(H2O)} (1), {[Co(ppda)(dpyo)(H2O)3]⋅4(H2O)} n  (2), and {[Co(ppda)(bpe)]⋅(0.5H2O)} n  (3) [ppda = 1,4-phenylenediacrylate; phen = 1,10-phenanthroline; dpyo = 4,4'-dipyridyl N,N'-dioxide; bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane]. These compounds exhibit diverse structural dimensions: 1 is a discrete dinuclear complex, 2 is a 1D coordination polymer, while 3 is a 3D three-fold interpenetrated network. Hydrogen-bonding and π-π stacking interactions of aromatic rings lead to a 3D supramolecular architecture in both complexes 1 and 2.

elements.content: High-purity 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)­ethane (bpe) (98%), 1,4-phenylenediacrylic acid (H2ppda) (97%), 4,4′-dipyridyl N,N′-dioxide (dpyo), 1,10-phenanthroline monohydrate, and manganese(II) chloride tetrahydrate (98%) were purchased from the Aldrich Chemical Co. Inc. and were used. All other chemicals were of AR grade.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

High-purity 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe) (98%), 1,4-phenylenediacrylic acid (H2ppda) (97%), 4,4'-dipyridyl N,N'-dioxide (dpyo), 1,10-phenanthroline monohydrate, and manganese(II) chloride tetrahydrate (98%) were purchased from the Aldrich Chemical Co. Inc. and were used. All other chemicals were of AR grade.

elements.content: Elemental analyses (carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen) were performed using a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a Bruker Vector 22FT IR spectrophotometer operating from 400 to 4000 cm–1. The UV/vis reflectance spectra were recorded between 200–1400 nm on a UV-3600, Shimadzu UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer at room temperature in the solid state. BaSO4 powder was used as a standard (baseline). Emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-7000 spectrofluorimeter at room temperature.

The complexes have been synthesized by adopting the procedures schematically given in Scheme .

Synthesis of {[Mn<sub>2</sub>(ppda)­(phen)<sub>4</sub>­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·(ppda)·2(H<sub>2</sub>O)} (<bold>1</bold>)

A methanolic solution (10 mL) of manganese(II) chloride tetrahydrate (1 mmol, 0.197 g) was added dropwise to a methanolic solution (10 mL) of 1,10-phenanthroline monohydrate (1 mmol; 0.198 g) and stirred for 15 min at room temperature (25 °C). Then, an aqueous solution (20 mL) of disodium 1,4-phenylenediacrylate (Na2ppda) (1 mmol, 0.262 g) was poured slowly into it, and the resulting mixture was refluxed for 4 h at 80 °C. It was then allowed to cool and filtered. The filtrate was kept in air for slow evaporation, and yellow-colored single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after a few days. Yield: 1.028 g (75%). Anal. Calcd. for C72H60­Mn2N8O14 (1371.16): C, 63.01; H, 4.37; N, 8.16%. Found: C, 63.59; H, 4.38; N, 8.15 (%). IR (cm–1): 3491(w), 3358(w), 3050(w), 1707(s), 1636(s), 1563(s), 1513(s), 1423(vs), 1372(vw), 1288(w), 1257(vw), 1144(w), 1102(w), 979(s), 856(w), 838(s), 784(vw), 768(vw), 728(s), 703(w), 635(w), 544(w), 507(vw), 419(vw).

elements.content: A methanolic solution (5 mL) of 4,4′-dipyridyl N,N′-dioxide (dpyo) (1 mmol, 0.188 g) was added dropwise to a methanolic solution (5 mL) of CoCl2·6H2O (1 mmol, 0.291 g) with constant stirring at room temperature (25 °C). An aqueous solution (10 mL) of disodium 1,4-phenylenediacrylate (Na2ppda) (1 mmol, 0.262 g) was added to the resulting light-red reaction mixture and stirred for 3 h. A deep-red complex separated out. Single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by diffusing a methanolic solution (10 mL) of dpyo and CoCl2·6H2O (1:1) mixture into an aqueous (10 mL) layer containing disodium 1,4-phenylenediacrylate (Na2ppda) in a tube. Deep-pink crystals deposited at the junction of the two layers after a few days. Yield: 0.471 g (80%). Anal. Calcd for C22H30­CoN2O13 (589.41): C, 44.79; H, 5.08; N, 4.75 (%). Found: C, 44.77; H, 5.10; N, 4.73(%). IR (cm–1): 3453(w), 3344(w), 3015(vw), 1638(s), 1537(s), 1418(w), 1389(s), 1295(vw), 1259(w), 1195(vw), 1113(vw), 984(vs), 888(w), 837(s), 741(vw), 699(w), 550(vw), 512(w).

elements.content: Data collections for complexes 1, 2, and 3 were carried out at room temperature with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker Smart Apex diffractometer equipped with CCD. Cell refinement, indexing and scaling of the data sets were done by using Bruker Smart Apex and Bruker Saint packages. The structures have been solved by direct methods and subsequent Fourier analyses and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method based on F 2 with all observed reflections. On the ΔFourier map of 3, a ppda anion and one py ring of the bpe were found disordered: the former is located about a center of symmetry (occupancy 0.5), and the second due to rotational disorder was refined over two positions with occupancies refined at 0.506(8)/0.494(8). Hydrogen atoms were placed at calculated positions; those of lattice water molecules were located on the ΔFourier map and refined. A residual in complex 3 was successfully refined as a water oxygen at half occupancy (H atoms not located). All the calculations were performed using the WinGX System, Ver 1.80.05. Crystal data and details of refinements are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement

Data collections for complexes 1, 2, and 3 were carried out at room temperature with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) on a Bruker Smart Apex diffractometer equipped with CCD. Cell refinement, indexing and scaling of the data sets were done by using Bruker Smart Apex and Bruker Saint packages. The structures have been solved by direct methods and subsequent Fourier analyses and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method based on F 2 with all observed reflections. On the ΔFourier map of 3, a ppda anion and one py ring of the bpe were found disordered: the former is located about a center of symmetry (occupancy 0.5), and the second due to rotational disorder was refined over two positions with occupancies refined at 0.506(8)/0.494(8). Hydrogen atoms were placed at calculated positions; those of lattice water molecules were located on the ΔFourier map and refined. A residual in complex 3 was successfully refined as a water oxygen at half occupancy (H atoms not located). All the calculations were performed using the WinGX System, Ver 1.80.05. Crystal data and details of refinements are given in Table .

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Measurements

Temperature-dependent molar susceptibility measurements of polycrystalline samples of 1-3 were carried out at the ‘‘Servei de Magnetoquímica (Universitat de Barcelona)'' in a Quantum Design SQUID MPMSXL susceptometer with an applied field of 3000 and 198 G in the temperature ranges of 2-300 and 2-30 K, respectively. For 3, molecular susceptibility measurements were also done at 10000, 5000, 100, and 50 G in the temperature range of 2-300 K. Magnetization curves were collected for 2 between 2 and 10 K in the magnetic field range of 0-5000 G.

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Description

[Mn2(ppda)(phen)4(H2O)2]⋅(ppda)⋅2(H2O) (1)

The crystal structure of complex 1 consists of discrete dinuclear [Mn2(ppda)(phen)4-(H2O)2]+cations, ppda anions, and lattice water molecules. The centrosymmetrical complex cation, shown in Figure , comprises two [Mn(phen)2(H2O)] units connected by a ppda in a bis-monodentate fashion spacing the metals by 15.594 Å. The manganese atom presents a highly distorted octahedral geometry with Mn-N bond lengths in a range 2.295(3)-2.305(3) Å, whereas the Mn-O bonds are somewhat shorter of 2.119(2) and 2.126(2) Å (Table ). These values are closely comparable to those found in the 1D polymeric compound [Mn(ppda)(phen)(H2O)2]. In the present complex, the occurrence of a second phen ligand in the metal sphere hampers the formation of a coordination polymeric species. The phenanthroline ligands coordinate the Mn atom with a chelating angle of ca. 72° and are arranged so that their mean planes make a dihedral angle of 66.20(5)°. The aqua ligand forms H-bonds with carboxylate groups of two uncoordinated ppda rather to form an intramolecular H-bond with the adjacent carboxylate oxygen O(2).

The crystal packing reveals the formation of π–π stacking interactions among aromatic rings of the py rings and ppda in addition to H-bonds due to the numerous water molecules. As far as aromatic ring interactions, both phen ligands are involved: the N3,N4-phenanthrolines of symmetry related complexes sandwich the uncoordinated ppda (centroid-to-centroid distances of 3.755(3) Å, Table 1S, ), as shown in Figure and Figure 1S (). Moreover, the central ring of the N3,N4 phen ligand stacks with a symmetry related one (centroid-to-centroid distances of 3.599(4) Å), and the N1-pyridine of each complex is faced to the central ring of the N1,N2-phen of a symmetry related moiety at a distance of 3.655(2) Å (Figure 2S, ). All of these interactions give rise to a 3D network arrangement. In addition, the aqua ligand O(1w) and the two lattice water molecules are involved in the formation of a H-bonding scheme with dppa oxygens, which results in an R 3 4(12) supramolecular synthon (Figure 1S). The structural parameters of these interactions are reported in Table 3S ().

elements.content: The X-ray structural analysis of complex 2 revealed that it is a 1D polymeric chain −[Co1–ppda–Co2–ppda] n – comprising two independent cobalt ions, having an O6 donor set in an octahedral centrosymmetric environment and linked by the bis-monodentate ppda anions at a distance of 16.132 Å (Figure ). The metal ion Co(2) is coordinated by four aqua ligands and two oxygens from different ppda, while Co(1) has two water molecules and two oxygens from ppda and completes the coordination sphere by two oxygen donors from different dipyridyl dioxide molecules. The latter ligands result to be monodentate and pendant from the polymeric array. The selected bond distances reported in Table indicate that the Co–O bond lengths fall in a range from 2.0375(14) to 2.1564(18) Å, the longest value being relative to the Co(2)–O(3w) bond distance. However, it is not obvious to correlate the variation of these Co–Ow values with the H-bonds formed by the aqua ligands (see below). The polymeric array is reinforced by rather strong intramolecular H-bonds, occurring between the coordinated water molecules and adjacent carboxylate O atoms, the O(1w)···O(4) and O(2w)···O(6) distances being 2.676 and 2.690 Å, respectively. The dpyo ligand, connected to the metal with a N(1)–O(1)–Co(1) angle of 120.18(11)°, is tilted by ca. 32° with respect to the direction of the polymer propagation. Symmetry related polymers are piled and connected through strong π–π stacking interactions between the dpyo pyridine and the ppda phenyl rings (centroid-to-centroid distance is 3.489(13) Å, Table 2S, ) to give rise to a 2D layer parallel to the crystallographic [102] planes (Figure ). In addition, the layered architecture is reinforced by H-bonds between the coordinated water O(3w) and oxygen O(2) of the terminal dpyo molecule. A 3D architecture is finally obtained through a H-bonding scheme involving the coordinated aqua ligands and the lattice water molecules with an R 4 4(12) supramolecular synthon (Figure 3S and Table 3S, ).

The X-ray structural analysis of complex 2 revealed that it is a 1D polymeric chain -[Co1-ppda-Co2-ppda] n - comprising two independent cobalt ions, having an O6 donor set in an octahedral centrosymmetric environment and linked by the bis-monodentate ppda anions at a distance of 16.132 Å (Figure ). The metal ion Co(2) is coordinated by four aqua ligands and two oxygens from different ppda, while Co(1) has two water molecules and two oxygens from ppda and completes the coordination sphere by two oxygen donors from different dipyridyl dioxide molecules. The latter ligands result to be monodentate and pendant from the polymeric array. The selected bond distances reported in Table  indicate that the Co-O bond lengths fall in a range from 2.0375(14) to 2.1564(18) Å, the longest value being relative to the Co(2)-O(3w) bond distance. However, it is not obvious to correlate the variation of these Co-Ow values with the H-bonds formed by the aqua ligands (see below). The polymeric array is reinforced by rather strong intramolecular H-bonds, occurring between the coordinated water molecules and adjacent carboxylate O atoms, the O(1w)⋅⋅⋅O(4) and O(2w)⋅⋅⋅O(6) distances being 2.676 and 2.690 Å, respectively. The dpyo ligand, connected to the metal with a N(1)-O(1)-Co(1) angle of 120.18(11)°, is tilted by ca. 32° with respect to the direction of the polymer propagation. Symmetry related polymers are piled and connected through strong π-π stacking interactions between the dpyo pyridine and the ppda phenyl rings (centroid-to-centroid distance is 3.489(13) Å, Table 2S, ) to give rise to a 2D layer parallel to the crystallographic [102] planes (Figure ). In addition, the layered architecture is reinforced by H-bonds between the coordinated water O(3w) and oxygen O(2) of the terminal dpyo molecule. A 3D architecture is finally obtained through a H-bonding scheme involving the coordinated aqua ligands and the lattice water molecules with an R 4 4(12) supramolecular synthon (Figure 3S and Table 3S, ).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of complex 3 contains a cobalt ion, a bpe ligand, and two half ppda anions. A residual in the difference Fourier map was assigned to lattice water oxygen of half occupancy. As shown in Figure , the cobalt ion is octahedrally coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of two bpe ligands and four oxygen atoms from three ppda anions. Both the independent ppda anions are hinged on inversion centers and thus symmetrically connect the cobalt atoms in two coordination modes: one bridges four Co atoms with carboxylate groups in a syn–syn fashion (η4μ2:μ2); the other acts as bis-chelating (η4μ) toward two Co atoms (Chart ). In the former case, an eight-membered ring [Co­(COO)]2 is formed, where the metals are separated by 4.3395(12) Å. The Co–O distances relative to the chelating carboxylates are slightly longer (Co–O(3) = 2.173(3) Å, Co–O(4) = 2.201(3) Å) with respect to those of bridging groups (Co–O(1) = 1.994(3) Å, Co–O(2′) = 2.021(3) Å), while the Co–N bond lengths of 2.165(3) and 2.152(4) Å are comparable within their esd (Table ). The measured intermetallic distance within the eight-membered ring [Co­(COO)]2 is comparable with the values of 4.00–4.40 Å detected in structures comprising similar binuclear nodes. These distances appear to be modulated by the different ligands used and ultimately by packing forces.

elements.content: Similar coordinated frameworks of formulation [M(tp)­(4,4′-bipy)] (M = Co, Cd, Zn; tp = terephthalate; 4,4′-bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine), which present a two-fold interpenetration network, have been already reported a decade ago. Interestingly, the use of a longer N,N′-donor ligand and dicarboxylate anion as connectors in 3 led to a comparable architecture, but the order of interpenetration is increased to three-fold. A three-fold interpenetrated compound structurally similar with different bridging spacers, [CoL­(bpdc)] (L = N,N′-bis-pyridin-4-ylmethylene-naphthalene-1,5-diamine and bpdcH2 = biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid) has been also reported, however, not identified or described as sqc65 o pcu three-fold in the original paper.

elements.content: The different dimensionality observed in the synthesized compounds are addressed by the different types of ligands used. In fact, the two ancillary phen ligands in 1 impede the formation of coordination polymers and polymeric species of higher dimensionality in the 1D complex 2 are likely disadvantaged by the water molecules forming H-bonding interactions.

elements.content: The most important absorption bands in IR spectroscopy of the complexes under study are summarized in the and tabulated in Table 4S (). The spectra (Figures 5S–7S, ) of complexes 1, 2, and 3 exhibit bands at 1636, 1638 and 1641 cm–1, respectively, corresponding to νas(OCO), while the νs(OCO) appears at 1423, 1418, and 1426 cm–1, respectively. Aromatic ν(CC, CN) stretching vibrations for 1, 2, and 3 appear in the regions of 1513–1563, 1537, and 1509–1612 cm–1, respectively. The bands in the region of 3015–3050 cm–1 correspond to the aromatic ν(C–H) stretching vibrations. The spectra of complexes 1, 2, and 3 show broad bands in the region of 3100–3550 cm–1, which are assigned to the ν(O–H) stretching vibrations of water molecules. For 3, the band at 2910 cm–1 is due to the ν(C–H)aliphatic stretching vibration. The bands at 1195 and 837 cm–1 correspond to ν(N–O) and δ(N–O) vibrations, respectively, for 2. The IR spectra of 1 and 2 also show bands corresponding to ρr(H2O) (at 768 cm–1 for 1, 741 cm–1 for 2) and to ρw(H2O) (at 544 cm–1 for 1, 550 cm–1 for 2), indicating the presence of coordinated water molecules.

IR Spectral Studies

The most important absorption bands in IR spectroscopy of the complexes under study are summarized in the  and tabulated in Table 4S (). The spectra (Figures 5S-7S, ) of complexes 1, 2, and 3 exhibit bands at 1636, 1638 and 1641 cm-1, respectively, corresponding to νas(OCO), while the νs(OCO) appears at 1423, 1418, and 1426 cm-1, respectively. Aromatic ν(CC, CN) stretching vibrations for 1, 2, and 3 appear in the regions of 1513-1563, 1537, and 1509-1612 cm-1, respectively. The bands in the region of 3015-3050 cm-1 correspond to the aromatic ν(C-H) stretching vibrations. The spectra of complexes 1, 2, and 3 show broad bands in the region of 3100-3550 cm-1, which are assigned to the ν(O-H) stretching vibrations of water molecules. For 3, the band at 2910 cm-1 is due to the ν(C-H)aliphatic stretching vibration. The bands at 1195 and 837 cm-1 correspond to ν(N-O) and δ(N-O) vibrations, respectively, for 2. The IR spectra of 1 and 2 also show bands corresponding to ρr(H2O) (at 768 cm-1 for 1, 741 cm-1 for 2) and to ρw(H2O) (at 544 cm-1 for 1, 550 cm-1 for 2), indicating the presence of coordinated water molecules.

elements.content: The solid-state reflectance spectra of all the complexes have been recorded (Figure 8S, ), and the data are collected in Table 5S (). For complex 1, no characteristic spin-allowed d–d electronic transitions are observed in the electronic spectra. A series of bands in the region of 23148–33003 cm–1 can be assigned to a spin-forbidden transition to spin quartets [ν̅, 23 148 cm–1; λ, 432 nm for 6A1g(S) → 4T2g(G); ν̅, 25 000 cm–1; λ, 400 nm for 6A1g(S) → 4A1g(G); ν̅, 25 252 cm–1; λ, 396 nm for 6A1g(S) → 4Eg(G); ν̅, 29 761 cm–1; λ, 336 nm for 6A1g(S) → 4Eg(D); and ν̅, 33 003 cm–1; λ, 303 nm for 6A1g(S) → 4T1g(P)] along with intraligand charge-transfer transitions of the organic ligand. For complexes 2 and 3, the band in the region of 8382–8568 cm–1 (ν̅, 8382 cm–1; λ, 1193 nm for 2 and ν̅, 8568 cm–1; λ, 1167 nm for 3) can be assigned to the spin-allowed d–d transition 4T1g(F) → 4T2g(F). In addition, a multiple band, observed in the visible region at 514 nm (19 455 cm–1) and 491 nm (20 366 cm–1) for 2 and 3, respectively, can be assigned to another spin-allowed d–d transition 4T1g(F) → 4T1g(P) admixed with a spin-forbidden transition to the doublet state derived principally from the free ion 2G and 2H terms. A very weak band (ν̅2), 620 nm (16 129 cm–1) and 617 nm (16 207 cm–1) for 2 and 3, respectively, corresponds to the spin-allowed 4T1g(F) → 4A2g(F) transition. From the Orgel diagram (ignoring configuration interaction) for weak field octahedral cobalt(II) (d7) compounds, it is clear that ν̅1 = 8Dq, ν̅2 = 18Dq, and ν̅3 = 6Dq + 15B. This relation allowed calculating the 10Dq and B values for the two compounds. The former values (10Dq) of 7746 and 7638 cm–1 for 2 and 3, respectively, (Table 5S, ) indicate that the ligand field strength for 2 is relatively higher with respect to that of 3. Calculated B values are 987 and 1052 cm–1 for 2 and 3, respectively.

elements.content: The emission spectra of complexes 1, 2, and 3 in the solid state at room temperature are depicted in Figure . It can be observed that intense emissions occur at 394 and 467 nm (λex = 270 nm) for 1, 465 nm (λex = 275 nm) for 2, and 415 nm (λex = 300 nm) for 3. These emissions may be assigned as intraligand charge transfer (ILCT) of the neutral N/O donor ligands.

elements.content: Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements on a polycrystalline sample of complex 1 were carried out with an applied field of 0.3 T in the temperature range of 1.9–300 K. The plot of χM T versus T is shown in Figure , where χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility and T is the absolute temperature. The χM T value measured at room temperature, of 8.48 cm3 mol–1 K, roughly matches the expected value of 8.74 cm3 mol–1 K obtained from the sum of two Mn(II) ions. Upon cooling, χM T keeps constant until a temperature of 50 K. Below this temperature, the χM T versus T curve starts decreasing until a χM T value of 8.12 cm3 mol–1 K is reached. The behavior displayed by complex 1 suggests the presence of an overall antiferromagnetic interaction between the Mn(II) ions in the dinuclear unit. In order to quantitatively interpret these data, a simulation was performed with the MAGPACK program in an attempt to reproduce the experimental curve. In this model, the crystallographic equivalence of the two Mn(II) ions in the dinuclear unit was considered by assigning one single g value for that ion. For the spin Hamiltonian H = −JS 1 S 2, S 1 = S 2 = S Mn, a good agreement between the experimental and simulated curves for 1 was found by using the following parameters: g Mn = 1.97 and J Mn–Mn = −0.02 cm–1. The simulated curve is represented together with the experimental values in Figure .

Magnetic Properties

Complex 1 

Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements on a polycrystalline sample of complex 1 were carried out with an applied field of 0.3 T in the temperature range of 1.9-300 K. The plot of χM T versus T is shown in Figure , where χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility and T is the absolute temperature. The χM T value measured at room temperature, of 8.48 cm3 mol-1 K, roughly matches the expected value of 8.74 cm3 mol-1 K obtained from the sum of two Mn(II) ions. Upon cooling, χM T keeps constant until a temperature of 50 K. Below this temperature, the χM T versus T curve starts decreasing until a χM T value of 8.12 cm3 mol-1 K is reached. The behavior displayed by complex 1 suggests the presence of an overall antiferromagnetic interaction between the Mn(II) ions in the dinuclear unit. In order to quantitatively interpret these data, a simulation was performed with the MAGPACK program in an attempt to reproduce the experimental curve. In this model, the crystallographic equivalence of the two Mn(II) ions in the dinuclear unit was considered by assigning one single g value for that ion. For the spin Hamiltonian H = -JS 1 S 2, S 1 = S 2 = S Mn, a good agreement between the experimental and simulated curves for 1 was found by using the following parameters: g Mn = 1.97 and J Mn-Mn = -0.02 cm-1. The simulated curve is represented together with the experimental values in Figure .

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 2 under the form of χM T versus T plot (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per Co(II) ion) are shown in Figure . χM T at room temperature is equal to 2.58 cm3 mol–1 K, a value that is larger than the expected one for the spin-only case (χM T = 1.875 cm3 mol–1 K with S Co = 3/2 and g Co = 2.0). This fact indicates that the distortion of the octahedral symmetry of Co(II) in 2 is not so large to induce the total quenching of the 4T1g ground state. Upon cooling, initially, χM T decreases smoothly and later faster. Below 50 K, χM T shows a tendency that would lead to a nonzero value at 0 K (around 1.6 cm3 mol–1 K). However, below 20 K, the χM T abruptly decreases, reaching a value of 1.14 cm3 mol–1 K at 2.0 K, but no maximum is observed in the magnetic susceptibility in the temperature range explored. The decrease of the χM T in the high-temperature region is due to the progressive depopulation of the high-energy Kramers doublets (spin–orbit coupling effects), as expected for six coordinated high-spin cobalt(II) complexes. This interpretation is supported by the fact that the value of χM T at 20 K and that expected at 0 K from the followed trend at high temperatures (1.92 and 1.6 cm3 mol–1 K, respectively) is well above in one case or close in the other to that calculated for a magnetically isolated cobalt(II) ion (1.73 cm3 mol–1 K for a S eff = 1/2 with g ≈ 4.3). The decrease of χM T below 20 K, which takes values lower than that calculated for a magnetically isolated cobalt(II) ion, can be interpreted as due to an overall weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the Co(II) ions through the L extended ligand. The magnetic susceptibility data for 2 were analyzed in the region T > 30 K by introducing SOC effects through the Hamiltonian Ĥ = α λ L̂ · Ŝ + Δ [ L̂ z 2 − L̂ ( L̂ + 1 ) / 3 ] + δ ( L̂ x 2 − L̂ y 2 ) + β H · ( − α L̂ + g e Ŝ ) where λ is the spin–orbit coupling parameter, α is the orbital reduction factor, and Δ is the axial orbital splitting of the T 1 term. Using the VPMAG package, the best-fit (dashed line in Figure ) was found with the values λ = −145 cm–1, α = 1.271, and Δ = 967 cm–1, with an agreement factor F of 2.0 × 10–5, defined as F = ∑[(χM T)exp – (χM T)calc]2/​∑[(χM T)exp]2. However, this model is not able to reproduce the experimental data below 20 K, which have been interpreted including a magnetic interaction between neighboring Co(II) ions. Thus, the system can be studied as a regular S = 1/2 chain with an effective g factor and magnetic coupling. The effective g value at each temperature is obtained from the χM T value of a Co(II) ion extrapolated from the SOC Hamiltonian discussed above, while the effective magnetic coupling constant is expressed as J eff = 25/9J, J being the true magnetic coupling between two S = 3/2 CoII ions. This methodology was extensively described in a precedent paper. A weak antiferromagnetic interaction between Co(II) ions is expected because their influence on the magnetic behavior is only observable at very low temperatures. In such a case, it is also possible to use a regular ring model of S = 1/2 centers to simulate the experimental behavior. When magnetic interaction is stronger, the data at lower temperatures are more poorly described and a higher temperature threshold is expected. Evidently, smaller ring models restrict fast the temperature region in which magnetic behavior can be correctly simulated. In this case, it is possible to simplify the study using a ring model with 10 centers that is large enough to process the experimental data of 2 and that can be done automatically with the VPMAG code including the spin–orbit coupling phenomenon and the effective interaction Hamiltonian. The best-fit (solid line in Figure ) was found with the values λ = −130 cm–1, α = 1.341, Δ = 1007 cm–1, and J = −0.3 cm–1, with an agreement factor F = 8.5 × 10–5. On the other hand, when Δ is large enough and positive, as in this case, only the two lowest Kramers doublets, arising from the 4A2 ground term, are thermally populated and the energy gap between them can be considered as an axial zero-field splitting (ZFS) within the quartet state with a positive D value. Therefore, the magnetic behavior can be analyzed by using the Hamiltonian H = D[S z 2 – S(S + 1)/3] + E(S x 2 – S y 2) + gμ B HS, where S is the spin ground state, D and E are the axial and transverse magnetic anisotropies, respectively, μB is the Bohr magneton, and H is the applied magnetic field. The isothermal M vs H /T plots (Figure ) for 2 are not superimposed on a single master curve, being a clear evidence of the presence of significant magnetic anisotropy. Since the antiferromagnetic coupling in 2 is slightly affected by the temperature interval in which the magnetization data have been collected, an easy and simultaneous analysis of the susceptibility and magnetization data cannot be performed, as previously done in other cases. Thus, only susceptibility data at T > 30 K were analyzed with this model. The values of parameters providing the best-fit were: g = 2.298 cm–1, D = +46.5 cm–1, E = −2.1 cm–1, and TIP = 3.4 × 10–4 cm3 mol–1, with an agreement factor F = 4.5*10–6. Similar values were found from a fit until 2 K, which included a magnetic interaction along a regular chain of effective spin 1/2. These values were: g = 2.376 cm–1, D = +49.6 cm–1, E = −1.4 cm–1, and J = −0.38 cm–1, with an agreement factor F = 1.2 × 10–4. Thus, a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between CoII ions confirms the previous best-fit and spin–orbit coupling model.

elements.content: The χM T versus T plot of 3 (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per Co(II) ion) is shown in Figure . Likewise in 2, χM T at room temperature (2.61 cm3 mol–1 K) is larger than the expected one for the spin-only case. The χM T values decrease faster with decreasing temperature until an abrupt decrease is observed below 10 K. Thus, spin–orbit coupling affects the behavior of compound 3 and weak antiferromagnetic couplings are observed. From Figures and , it seems that the magnetic couplings are weaker in 3, probably, because of the less planarity in some of the extended ligands involved in the magnetic connection of the CoII ions. However, an unexpected sharp and irregular increase of χM T around 60 K is observed. After it, a maximum of χM T (5.07 cm3 mol–1 K with an applied magnetic field equal to 100 G) is reached at 43 K. This behavior, which is typical of a magnetic order, is dependent on the applied magnetic field (Figure ), but only in the intermediate temperature region, i.e., below 5 K and above 60 K; the measured χM T values in the presence of several magnetic fields are superimposed. Moreover, this maximum diminishes significantly in the presence of higher magnetic fields and the recorded signals are very weak, which allows us to conclude that this unusual behavior corresponds to the presence of a magnetic impurity that is magnetically ordered below 60 K. The coprecipitation of several phases of cobalt(II) hydroxides that show this kind of magnetic order is a usual phenomenon in the synthesis of such a type of coordination compounds. Several attempts to remove these impurities were done, but they were all unsuccessful. Unfortunately, under such circumstances, it was not possible to analyze the magnetic behavior of 3 similarly as performed for complex 2.

Complex 3 

The χM T versus T plot of 3 (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per Co(II) ion) is shown in Figure . Likewise in 2, χM T at room temperature (2.61 cm3 mol-1 K) is larger than the expected one for the spin-only case. The χM T values decrease faster with decreasing temperature until an abrupt decrease is observed below 10 K. Thus, spin-orbit coupling affects the behavior of compound 3 and weak antiferromagnetic couplings are observed. From Figures  and , it seems that the magnetic couplings are weaker in 3, probably, because of the less planarity in some of the extended ligands involved in the magnetic connection of the CoII ions. However, an unexpected sharp and irregular increase of χM T around 60 K is observed. After it, a maximum of χM T (5.07 cm3 mol-1 K with an applied magnetic field equal to 100 G) is reached at 43 K. This behavior, which is typical of a magnetic order, is dependent on the applied magnetic field (Figure ), but only in the intermediate temperature region, i.e., below 5 K and above 60 K; the measured χM T values in the presence of several magnetic fields are superimposed. Moreover, this maximum diminishes significantly in the presence of higher magnetic fields and the recorded signals are very weak, which allows us to conclude that this unusual behavior corresponds to the presence of a magnetic impurity that is magnetically ordered below 60 K. The coprecipitation of several phases of cobalt(II) hydroxides that show this kind of magnetic order is a usual phenomenon in the synthesis of such a type of coordination compounds. Several attempts to remove these impurities were done, but they were all unsuccessful. Unfortunately, under such circumstances, it was not possible to analyze the magnetic behavior of 3 similarly as performed for complex 2.

elements.content: With regard to other compounds reported in the literature with structural analogies with complexes 1–3, few of these systems have been magnetically studied so far, especially for what concerns Co(II) complexes. For most of these, no magnetic study is reported or the magnetic behavior is interpreted by using the Curie–Weiss law where no single-ion effects from Co(II) are considered. Just in a few cases, the approach, originally described by Lloret et al. and applied in the present paper, has been used. However, even in these cases, the structural differences among the reported compounds and the presence of unquenched spin–orbit coupling in octahedral Co(II) coordination complexes make it difficult to draw further conclusions or magneto-structural correlations with current available tools. Nevertheless, the analysis of the magnetic behavior of compounds involving paramagnetic ions bridged by long carboxylato-based ligands shows similar trends as observed in complexes 1–3. In 1, where no spin–orbit is present, the exchange interaction between Mn(II) ions is very weak, as also detected in complexes 2 and 3, and in the examples of the literature, since the long metal–metal distance through these ligands (ca. 13 Å) does not effectively transmit an exchange. In case of complex 3, where two Co(II) ions are linked by two syn–syn carboxylate groups, a weak antiferromagnetic exchange has been observed between the metals in agreement with the weak J Co–Co constants found in the literature for multiple carboxylato-bridged Co(II) complexes.

elements.content: In summary, we have presented here the synthesis, crystal structure, and low-temperature magnetic behavior of three novel 1,4-phenylenediacrylate (ppda) bridged complexes of manganese(II)/cobalt(II) using N,N′ and O,O′ donor neutral ligands. Manganese(II)–ppda in combination with a chelating phen ligand (1) and cobalt(II)–ppda with a rigid rodlike dpyo ligand (2) generates a discrete dinuclear complex and 1D polymeric chain, respectively. In both of these, ppda shows a bis-monodentate binding mode. 3D supramolecular architectures in 1 and 2 are realized through H-bonding and π–π interactions. On the other hand, a 3D interpenetrated architecture is obtained by using cobalt(II) ions and long flexible connectors 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane in combination with ppda (3). Low-temperature magnetic study reveals weak antiferromagnetic coupling in all the complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have presented here the synthesis, crystal structure, and low-temperature magnetic behavior of three novel 1,4-phenylenediacrylate (ppda) bridged complexes of manganese(II)/cobalt(II) using N,N' and O,O' donor neutral ligands. Manganese(II)-ppda in combination with a chelating phen ligand (1) and cobalt(II)-ppda with a rigid rodlike dpyo ligand (2) generates a discrete dinuclear complex and 1D polymeric chain, respectively. In both of these, ppda shows a bis-monodentate binding mode. 3D supramolecular architectures in 1 and 2 are realized through H-bonding and π-π interactions. On the other hand, a 3D interpenetrated architecture is obtained by using cobalt(II) ions and long flexible connectors 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane in combination with ppda (3). Low-temperature magnetic study reveals weak antiferromagnetic coupling in all the complexes.

The complexes have been synthesized by adopting the procedures schematically given in Scheme .

Synthesis of {[Mn<sub>2</sub>(ppda)­(phen)<sub>4</sub>­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·(ppda)·2(H<sub>2</sub>O)} (<bold>1</bold>)

A methanolic solution (10 mL) of manganese(II) chloride tetrahydrate (1 mmol, 0.197 g) was added dropwise to a methanolic solution (10 mL) of 1,10-phenanthroline monohydrate (1 mmol; 0.198 g) and stirred for 15 min at room temperature (25 °C). Then, an aqueous solution (20 mL) of disodium 1,4-phenylenediacrylate (Na2ppda) (1 mmol, 0.262 g) was poured slowly into it, and the resulting mixture was refluxed for 4 h at 80 °C. It was then allowed to cool and filtered. The filtrate was kept in air for slow evaporation, and yellow-colored single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after a few days. Yield: 1.028 g (75%). Anal. Calcd. for C72H60­Mn2N8O14 (1371.16): C, 63.01; H, 4.37; N, 8.16%. Found: C, 63.59; H, 4.38; N, 8.15 (%). IR (cm–1): 3491(w), 3358(w), 3050(w), 1707(s), 1636(s), 1563(s), 1513(s), 1423(vs), 1372(vw), 1288(w), 1257(vw), 1144(w), 1102(w), 979(s), 856(w), 838(s), 784(vw), 768(vw), 728(s), 703(w), 635(w), 544(w), 507(vw), 419(vw).

Synthesis of {[Co(ppda)­(dpyo)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·4(H<sub>2</sub>O)}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A methanolic solution (5 mL) of 4,4′-dipyridyl N,N′-dioxide (dpyo) (1 mmol, 0.188 g) was added dropwise to a methanolic solution (5 mL) of CoCl2·6H2O (1 mmol, 0.291 g) with constant stirring at room temperature (25 °C). An aqueous solution (10 mL) of disodium 1,4-phenylenediacrylate (Na2ppda) (1 mmol, 0.262 g) was added to the resulting light-red reaction mixture and stirred for 3 h. A deep-red complex separated out. Single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by diffusing a methanolic solution (10 mL) of dpyo and CoCl2·6H2O (1:1) mixture into an aqueous (10 mL) layer containing disodium 1,4-phenylenediacrylate (Na2ppda) in a tube. Deep-pink crystals deposited at the junction of the two layers after a few days. Yield: 0.471 g (80%). Anal. Calcd for C22H30­CoN2O13 (589.41): C, 44.79; H, 5.08; N, 4.75 (%). Found: C, 44.77; H, 5.10; N, 4.73(%). IR (cm–1): 3453(w), 3344(w), 3015(vw), 1638(s), 1537(s), 1418(w), 1389(s), 1295(vw), 1259(w), 1195(vw), 1113(vw), 984(vs), 888(w), 837(s), 741(vw), 699(w), 550(vw), 512(w).

Synthesis of {[Co(ppda)­(bpe)]·(0.5H<sub>2</sub>O)}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

The complex was synthesized following the same procedure adopted for complex 2 using 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane (bpe) (1 mmol, 0.184 g) instead of dpyo. Single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by diffusing a methanolic solution (10 mL) of bpe and CoCl2·6H2O (1:1) mixture into an aqueous (10 mL) layer containing disodium 1,4-phenylenediacrylate (Na2ppda) in a tube. Deep-red crystals deposited at the junction of the two layers after a few days. Yield: 0.365 g (78%). Anal. Calcd for C24H21­CoN2O4.50 (468.36): C, 61.49; H, 4.48; N, 5.97 (%). Found: C, 61.47; H, 4.50; N, 5.96(%). IR (cm–1): 3000–3500(br,s), 1641(s), 1612(s), 1583(w), 1564(w), 1541(w), 1509(w), 1426(vs), 1393(vs), 1289(w), 1259(w), 1114(w), 1071(w), 1018(w), 983(s), 881(w), 830(s), 721(w), 695(w), 548(w), 507(vw).

IR (cm-1): 3453(w), 3344(w), 3015(vw), 1638(s), 1537(s), 1418(w), 1389(s), 1295(vw), 1259(w), 1195(vw), 1113(vw), 984(vs), 888(w), 837(s), 741(vw), 699(w), 550(vw), 512(w).

Synthesis of {[Co(ppda)(bpe)]⋅(0.5H2O)} n  (3)

The complex was synthesized following the same procedure adopted for complex 2 using 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe) (1 mmol, 0.184 g) instead of dpyo. Single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by diffusing a methanolic solution (10 mL) of bpe and CoCl2⋅6H2O (1:1) mixture into an aqueous (10 mL) layer containing disodium 1,4-phenylenediacrylate (Na2ppda) in a tube. Deep-red crystals deposited at the junction of the two layers after a few days. Yield: 0.365 g (78%). Anal. Calcd for C24H21CoN2O4.50 (468.36): C, 61.49; H, 4.48; N, 5.97 (%). Found: C, 61.47; H, 4.50; N, 5.96(%). IR (cm-1): 3000-3500(br,s), 1641(s), 1612(s), 1583(w), 1564(w), 1541(w), 1509(w), 1426(vs), 1393(vs), 1289(w), 1259(w), 1114(w), 1071(w), 1018(w), 983(s), 881(w), 830(s), 721(w), 695(w), 548(w), 507(vw).

cln_elements.content:
Finally, by using the program Platon, an effective free space of 12.0% of the crystal volume was calculated in 3 (142.4 out of the 1190.6 Å3 unit cell volume) and the three-fold interpenetrated structure, when viewed down the a axis, draws channels that are occupied by disordered lattice water molecules H-bonded to the ppda (Figure 4S, ).

Magnetic PropertiesComplex <bold>1</bold>

Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements on a polycrystalline sample of complex 1 were carried out with an applied field of 0.3 T in the temperature range of 1.9–300 K. The plot of χM T versus T is shown in Figure , where χM is the molar magnetic susceptibility and T is the absolute temperature. The χM T value measured at room temperature, of 8.48 cm3 mol–1 K, roughly matches the expected value of 8.74 cm3 mol–1 K obtained from the sum of two Mn(II) ions. Upon cooling, χM T keeps constant until a temperature of 50 K. Below this temperature, the χM T versus T curve starts decreasing until a χM T value of 8.12 cm3 mol–1 K is reached. The behavior displayed by complex 1 suggests the presence of an overall antiferromagnetic interaction between the Mn(II) ions in the dinuclear unit. In order to quantitatively interpret these data, a simulation was performed with the MAGPACK program in an attempt to reproduce the experimental curve. In this model, the crystallographic equivalence of the two Mn(II) ions in the dinuclear unit was considered by assigning one single g value for that ion. For the spin Hamiltonian H = −JS 1 S 2, S 1 = S 2 = S Mn, a good agreement between the experimental and simulated curves for 1 was found by using the following parameters: g Mn = 1.97 and J Mn–Mn = −0.02 cm–1. The simulated curve is represented together with the experimental values in Figure .

cln_elements.content: The magnetic properties of 2 under the form of χM T versus T plot (χM is the magnetic susceptibility per Co(II) ion) are shown in Figure . χM T at room temperature is equal to 2.58 cm3 mol–1 K, a value that is larger than the expected one for the spin-only case (χM T = 1.875 cm3 mol–1 K with S Co = 3/2 and g Co = 2.0). This fact indicates that the distortion of the octahedral symmetry of Co(II) in 2 is not so large to induce the total quenching of the 4T1g ground state. Upon cooling, initially, χM T decreases smoothly and later faster. Below 50 K, χM T shows a tendency that would lead to a nonzero value at 0 K (around 1.6 cm3 mol–1 K). However, below 20 K, the χM T abruptly decreases, reaching a value of 1.14 cm3 mol–1 K at 2.0 K, but no maximum is observed in the magnetic susceptibility in the temperature range explored. The decrease of the χM T in the high-temperature region is due to the progressive depopulation of the high-energy Kramers doublets (spin–orbit coupling effects), as expected for six coordinated high-spin cobalt(II) complexes. This interpretation is supported by the fact that the value of χM T at 20 K and that expected at 0 K from the followed trend at high temperatures (1.92 and 1.6 cm3 mol–1 K, respectively) is well above in one case or close in the other to that calculated for a magnetically isolated cobalt(II) ion (1.73 cm3 mol–1 K for a S eff = 1/2 with g ≈ 4.3). The decrease of χM T below 20 K, which takes values lower than that calculated for a magnetically isolated cobalt(II) ion, can be interpreted as due to an overall weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the Co(II) ions through the L extended ligand. The magnetic susceptibility data for 2 were analyzed in the region T > 30 K by introducing SOC effects through the Hamiltonian Ĥ = α λ L̂ · Ŝ + Δ [ L̂ z 2 − L̂ ( L̂ + 1 ) / 3 ] + δ ( L̂ x 2 − L̂ y 2 ) + β H · ( − α L̂ + g e Ŝ ) where λ is the spin–orbit coupling parameter, α is the orbital reduction factor, and Δ is the axial orbital splitting of the T 1 term. Using the VPMAG package, the best-fit (dashed line in Figure ) was found with the values λ = −145 cm–1, α = 1.271, and Δ = 967 cm–1, with an agreement factor F of 2.0 × 10–5, defined as F = ∑[(χM T)exp – (χM T)calc]2/​∑[(χM T)exp]2. However, this model is not able to reproduce the experimental data below 20 K, which have been interpreted including a magnetic interaction between neighboring Co(II) ions. Thus, the system can be studied as a regular S = 1/2 chain with an effective g factor and magnetic coupling. The effective g value at each temperature is obtained from the χM T value of a Co(II) ion extrapolated from the SOC Hamiltonian discussed above, while the effective magnetic coupling constant is expressed as J eff = 25/9J, J being the true magnetic coupling between two S = 3/2 CoII ions. This methodology was extensively described in a precedent paper. A weak antiferromagnetic interaction between Co(II) ions is expected because their influence on the magnetic behavior is only observable at very low temperatures. In such a case, it is also possible to use a regular ring model of S = 1/2 centers to simulate the experimental behavior. When magnetic interaction is stronger, the data at lower temperatures are more poorly described and a higher temperature threshold is expected. Evidently, smaller ring models restrict fast the temperature region in which magnetic behavior can be correctly simulated. In this case, it is possible to simplify the study using a ring model with 10 centers that is large enough to process the experimental data of 2 and that can be done automatically with the VPMAG code including the spin–orbit coupling phenomenon and the effective interaction Hamiltonian. The best-fit (solid line in Figure ) was found with the values λ = −130 cm–1, α = 1.341, Δ = 1007 cm–1, and J = −0.3 cm–1, with an agreement factor F = 8.5 × 10–5. On the other hand, when Δ is large enough and positive, as in this case, only the two lowest Kramers doublets, arising from the 4A2 ground term, are thermally populated and the energy gap between them can be considered as an axial zero-field splitting (ZFS) within the quartet state with a positive D value. Therefore, the magnetic behavior can be analyzed by using the Hamiltonian H = D[S z 2 – S(S + 1)/3] + E(S x 2 – S y 2) + gμ B HS, where S is the spin ground state, D and E are the axial and transverse magnetic anisotropies, respectively, μB is the Bohr magneton, and H is the applied magnetic field. The isothermal M vs H /T plots (Figure ) for 2 are not superimposed on a single master curve, being a clear evidence of the presence of significant magnetic anisotropy. Since the antiferromagnetic coupling in 2 is slightly affected by the temperature interval in which the magnetization data have been collected, an easy and simultaneous analysis of the susceptibility and magnetization data cannot be performed, as previously done in other cases. Thus, only susceptibility data at T > 30 K were analyzed with this model. The values of parameters providing the best-fit were: g = 2.298 cm–1, D = +46.5 cm–1, E = −2.1 cm–1, and TIP = 3.4 × 10–4 cm3 mol–1, with an agreement factor F = 4.5*10–6. Similar values were found from a fit until 2 K, which included a magnetic interaction along a regular chain of effective spin 1/2. These values were: g = 2.376 cm–1, D = +49.6 cm–1, E = −1.4 cm–1, and J = −0.38 cm–1, with an agreement factor F = 1.2 × 10–4. Thus, a weak antiferromagnetic interaction between CoII ions confirms the previous best-fit and spin–orbit coupling model.
